Detailed Description

This class is a wrapper around the PCRE library.

You can use this class to search in strings using reular expressions as well as getting matched sub strings. It does currently not support all features, which the underlying PCRE library provides, but the most important stuff is implemented. If you want to learn more about regular expressions which can be used with PCRE, then please read the following documentation: perlre - Perl regular expressions

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

UPCRE::UPCRE (  )  [inline]

Empty Constructor. Create a new empty UPCRE object. This is the simplest constructor available, you might consider one of the other constructors as a better solution. You need to initialize this UPCRE object, if you use the empty constructor. You can use the available method set() to assign it an expression

Returns:
A new empty UPCRE object
UPCRE::UPCRE ( const UString &  expression,
int  flags 
)

Compile the given pattern. An UPCRE object created this way can be used multiple times to do searches

Parameters:
expression a string, which must be a valid perl regular expression.
flags option bits can be one or more of the following bits:

  • PCRE_ANCHORED anchored pattern.
  • PCRE_CASELESS case insensitive search.
  • PCRE_DOLLAR_ENDONLY dollar sign matches only at end.
  • PCRE_DOTALL newline is contained in . (A dot in an expression matches newlines too, which is normally not the case)
  • PCRE_EXTENDED whitespace characters will be ignored (except within character classes or if escaped)
  • PCRE_EXTRA use perl incompatible pcre extensions
  • PCRE_MULTILINE match on multiple lines, thus ^ and $ are interpreted as the start and end of the entire string, not of a single line
  • PCRE_NO_AUTO_CAPTURE disable the use of numbered capturing parentheses in the pattern
  • PCRE_UNGREEDY quantifiers behave not greedy by default
  • PCRE_UTF8 use utf8 support.
  • PCRE_GLOBAL (internal flag) match multiple times - used only in the replace() method
See also:
pcreapi(3) manpage
Returns:
A new UPCRE object, which holds the compiled pattern.
UPCRE::UPCRE ( const UString &  expression,
const char *  flags = "" 
) [inline]

Compile the given pattern. An UPCRE object created this way can be used multiple times to do searches

Parameters:
expression a string, which must be a valid perl regular expression
flags can be one or more of the following letters:

  • i Search case insensitive
  • m Match on multiple lines, thus ^ and $ are interpreted as the start and end of the entire string, not of a single line
  • s A dot in an expression matches newlines too(which is normally not the case)
  • x Whitespace characters will be ignored (except within character classes or if escaped)
  • g Match multiple times. This flags affects only the behavior of the replace() method
Returns:
A new UPCRE object, which holds the compiled pattern.
UPCRE::~UPCRE (  )  [inline]

The destructor will automatically invoked if the object is no more used. It frees all the memory allocated by pcre.

Member Function Documentation

UString UPCRE::getMatch ( int  pos  )  [inline]

Get a substring at a known position

Parameters:
pos the position of the substring to return. Identical to perl's $1..$n
Returns:
the substring at the given position

Example: 

        UString mysub = regex.getMatch(1);

Get the first substring that matched the expression in the "regex" object

int UPCRE::getMatchEnd ( int  pos  )  [inline]

Get the end position of a substring within the searched string. This method returns the character position of the last character of a substring withing the searched string

Parameters:
pos the position of the substring. Identical to perl's $1..$n
Returns:
the integer character position of the last character of a substring. Positions are starting at 0

Example: 

        UPCRE regex("([0-9]+)");             // search for numerical characters
        regex.search("The 11th september."); // do the search on this string
        UString day = regex.getMatch(1);     // returns "11"
        int pos = regex.getMatchEnd(1);      // returns 5, because "11" ends at the 5th character inside the search string
See also:
int getMatchStart(int pos)
int getMatchStart()
int getMatchEnd()
int UPCRE::getMatchEnd (  )  [inline]

Get the end position of the entire match within the searched string. This method returns the character position of the last character of the entire match within the searched string

Returns:
the integer character position of the last character of the entire match

Example: 

        UPCRE regex("([0-9]+)\s([a-z]+)");   // search for the date (makes 2 substrings)
        regex.search("The 11th september."); // do the search on this string
        int pos = regex.getMatchEnd();       // returns 17, because "11th september", which is the entire match,
                                                                                                         // ends at the 17th character inside the search string
See also:
int getMatchStart()
int getMatchStart(int pos)
int getMatchEnd(int pos)

Parameters:
pos the position of the substring-length to return. Identical to perl's $1..$n
Returns:
the length substring at the given position
int UPCRE::getMatchStart ( int  pos  )  [inline]

Get the start position of a substring within the searched string. This method returns the character position of the first character of a substring withing the searched string

Parameters:
pos the position of the substring. Identical to perl's $1..$n
Returns:
the integer character position of the first character of a substring. Positions are starting at 0

Example: 

        UPCRE regex("([0-9]+)");             // search for numerical characters
        regex.search("The 11th september."); // do the search on this string
        UString day = regex.getMatch(1);     // returns "11"
        int pos = regex.getMatchStart(1);    // returns 4, because "11" begins at the 4th character inside the search string
See also:
int getMatchStart()
int getMatchEnd()
int getMatchEnd(int pos)
int UPCRE::getMatchStart (  )  [inline]

Get the start position of the entire match within the searched string. This method returns the character position of the first character of the entire match within the searched string

Returns:
the integer character position of the first character of the entire match Example: 
        UPCRE regex("([0-9]+)\s([a-z]+)");   // search for the date(makes 2 substrings
        regex.search("The 11th september."); // do the search on this string
        int pos = regex.getMatchStart();     // returns 4, because "11th september" begins at the 4th character
                                                                                                         // inside the search string
See also:
int getMatchStart(int pos)
int getMatchEnd(int pos)
int getMatchEnd()
pcre* UPCRE::getPcre (  )  [inline]

Return pointer to underlying pcre object. The pcre object allows you to access the pcre API directly. E.g. if your are using pcre version 4.x and want to use the new functionality which is currently not supported by the class. An example would be: pcre_fullinfo(), pcre_study() or the callout functionality

Returns:
pcre* pointer to pcre object.
See also:
man pcre
pcre_extra* getPcreExtra()
pcre_extra* UPCRE::getPcreExtra (  )  [inline]

Return pointer to underlying pcre_extra structure. The returned pcre_extra structure can be used in conjunction with the pcre* object returned by pcre()

Returns:
pcre_extra* pointer to pcre_extra structure.
See also:
pcre* getPcre()

Return a vector of substrings, if any

Returns:
a pointer to an UVector<UString>, which may be NULL, if no substrings has been found

Test if a search was successfull This method must be invoked after calling search()

Returns:
boolean true if the search was successfull at all, or false if not

UString UPCRE::replace ( const UString &  piece,
const UString &  with 
)

Replace parts of a string using regular expressions. This method is the counterpart of the perl s// operator. It replaces the substrings which matched the given regular expression (given to the constructor) with the supplied string

Parameters:
piece the string in which you want to search and replace
with the string which you want to place on the positions which match the expression (given to the constructor)
bool UPCRE::search ( const char *  stuff,
uint32_t  stuff_len = 0,
int  offset = 0,
int  options = 0 
)

Do a search on the given string beginning at the given offset.

Parameters:
stuff the string in which you want to search for something
offset the offset where to start the search
options can contain any combination of options PCRE_ANCHORED, PCRE_NOTBOL, PCRE_NOTEOL. PCRE_NOTEMPTY
Returns:
boolean true if the regular expression matched. false if not
void UPCRE::set ( const UString &  expression  )  [inline]

reset the object and re-intialize it

Parameters:
expression a string, which must be a valid perl regular expression
uint32_t UPCRE::split ( UVector< UString > &  vec,
const UString &  piece,
int  limit = 0,
int  start_offset = 0,
int  end_offset = 0 
)

split a string into pieces. This method will split the given string into a vector of strings using the compiled expression (given to the constructor)

Parameters:
vec an vector of strings
piece The string you want to split into it's parts
limit the maximum number of elements you want to get back from split()
start_offset at which substring the returned vector should start
end_offset at which substring the returned vector should end
Returns:
the number of split parts
void UPCRE::study ( int  options = 0  )  [inline]

Analyze pattern for speeding up the matching process. When a pattern is going to be used several times, it is worth spending more time analyzing it in order to speed up the time taken for matching.
